urls.title: Beavers build first Exmoor dam in 400 years
urls.description: The National Trust says the dam in Somerset "might look modest, but it is incredibly special".

tweets.text:
The first beaver dam in over 400 years appeared on Exmoor after beavers were released into the wild in January.

These rodents can play an important role in engineering the landscape and helping to restore streams and reduce #flooding.

Learn more: https://t.co/h7VascPfWg

Day 2 of reducing plastic at Christmas: avoid stockings with wrapped treats and throwaway items ‚ôªÔ∏è An extra 30% of rubbish is produced and discarded throughout the festive period! üéÑ @EnvAgency https://t.co/jhomgrgP1I

domain.name: TV Shows
domain.description: Television shows from around the world

entity.name: Downton Abbey
entity.description: This historical drama follows the lives of the Crawley family and their servants in the family's Edwardian country house. The programme begins with the 1912 sinking of the Titanic, which leaves Downton Abbey's future in jeopardy, as Lord Grantham's presumptive heir -- his cousin James -- and his son, Patrick, die aboard the ship, leaving him without a male offspring to take over the throne upon his death. As a result, Lord Grantham must search for a new heir. As the programme progresses through the decade, other historical events happen leading up to Lord Grantham declaring in 1914 that Britain is at war with Germany, marking the beginning of World War I, which becomes a major plot on the programme.

urls.title: Guest blog - How nature dies by Alistair Gammell - Mark Avery
urls.description: Alistair Gammell worked for RSPB for 40 years and was closely involved in the drafting of the Birds and Habitats Directives and for growing RSPB‚Äôs international work. He was RSPB‚Äôs first International Director and retired from RSPB in 2009. He then worked to successfully establish large scale fully protected marine reserves in the seas around the British Indian Ocean Territory and Pitcairn Island. He is a passionate nature conservationist and fly fisherman (alistairgammell@yahoo.co.uk) Oughton Head is a

tweets.text:
Caesar‚Äôs Camp in Swinley Forest is a large oak leaf-shaped univallate Iron Age Hillfort, with a 4m high rampart in places. Antiquarians named the site after Julius Caesar, mistaking the earthworks for a Roman camp left behind by his 55-54BC campaign. 

#HillfortsWednesday https://t.co/BP7ZIehuDo

Shame on you @grantshapps @BorisJohnson @nadams @RishiSunak - I don‚Äôt see how the @Conservatives can carry on using the oak tree as one of their symbols. You have done nothing but destroy and neglect @EnvAgency @NaturalEngland @Telegraph @piersmorgan https://t.co/NPPBVlnXN9
